intro: Chelidonium majus, commonly known as greater celandine, is a flowering plant native to Europe, western Asia, and North Africa. It is a member of the Papaveraceae family, which includes poppies, and is characterized by its yellow, saucer-shaped flowers and lobed leaves. The plant contains various alkaloids, including chelidonine, which has been used historically in traditional medicine. It thrives in disturbed soils and can often be found in meadows, roadsides, and waste areas. Its latex is toxic and can cause skin irritation, making it a plant to handle with care.
